section.title: Inverse Trigonometric Functions

introduction.p: In this chapter, we have evaluated trigonometric functions at various angles, but what if we need to know what angle yields a specific sine, cosine, or tangent value? To find angles, we need inverse trigonometric functions.

statement.p: If \cos(\theta)=-0.4, in which quadrants can \theta lie?

solution.p: Since our cosine value is negative and cosine corresponds to the x coordinate of a point on the unit circle, \theta could lie in Quadrant II or Quadrant III.

section.p: In the previous example, we were given a trigonometric value and could use the definition of cosine to determine the quadrants in which \theta could lie. However, in order to solve for \theta, we need an additional tool.

assemblage.title: Inverse Sine, Cosine, and Tangent Functions
assemblage.p: Note that the output of each of these inverse functions is an angle.

note.title: Common Notation
note.p: The inverse sine function, \sin^{-1}(a) is sometimes called the arcsine function, and notated \arcsin(a).
The inverse cosine function, \cos^{-1}(a) is sometimes called the arccosine function, and notated \arccos(a).
The inverse tangent function, \tan^{-1}(a) is sometimes called the arctangent function, and notated \arctan(a).

warning.p: Based only on the definitions above, the inverse trigonometric functions are not actually functions at all! For example, since \sin(0)=0 and \sin(2\pi)=0, we have that \arcsin(0)=0 and \arcsin(0)=2\pi.

This can be fixed by restricting the outputs to a certain interval. For example, most calculators will always give you an angle in either the interval [0,\pi] or [-\frac{\pi}{2},\frac{\pi}{2}], but not both.

statement.p: Find two angles in the interval [0,2\pi] such that \displaystyle \sin(\theta)=\frac{1}{2}.

solution.p: Since we are given a sine value, we know that we are looking for angles with a y coordinate of 1/2 on the unit circle.
From the common angles on the unit circle, the two angles where \sin(\theta)=1/2 in the interval [0,2\pi] are \theta = \frac{\pi}{6} \hspace{.25in} \text{and} \hspace{.25in} \theta = \frac{5\pi}{6}

statement.p: Find two angles in the interval [0,2\pi] such that \displaystyle \cos(\theta)=-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}.

solution.p: Since we are given a cosine value, we know that we are looking for angles with an x coordinate of -\sqrt{3}/2 on the unit circle.

From the common angles on the unit circle, the two angles where \cos(\theta)=-\sqrt{3}/2 in the interval [0,2\pi] are \theta = \frac{5\pi}{6} \hspace{.25in} \text{and} \hspace{.25in} \theta = \frac{7\pi}{6}

statement.p: Find two angles in the interval [0,2\pi] such that \tan(\theta)=1.

solution.p: Since we are given a tangent value of 1 and \tan(\theta) = y/x, we know that we are looking for angles where the x and y values are equal on the unit circle.

From the common angles on the unit circle, the two angles where the x and y values are equal and \tan(\theta)=1 in the interval [0,2\pi] are \theta = \frac{\pi}{4} \hspace{.25in} \text{and} \hspace{.25in} \theta = \frac{5\pi}{4}

statement.p: Find all angles in the interval \displaystyle [0,2\pi] such that \displaystyle \text{a.} \hspace{.1in} \sin(\theta)=-1 \hspace{.5in} \text{b.} \hspace{.1in} \cos(\theta)=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \hspace{.5in} \text{c.} \hspace{.1in} \tan(\theta)=\sqrt{3}

ol.label: a
ol.li: Since we are given a sine value of -1, we know that we are looking for angles where the y value is equal to -1. The only such angle in the interval \displaystyle [0,2\pi] is \theta=\frac{3\pi}{2}.

Since we are given a cosine value of \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}, we are looking for angles where the x value is equal to \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}. Fromt he common angles on the unit circle, the two angles in the interval \displaystyle [0,2\pi] are
\frac{\pi}{4} \hspace{.25in} \text{ and } \hspace{.25in} \frac{7\pi}{4}

section.p: In the previous examples and exercises, we were able to use the unit circle to solve for \theta, but if we are given trigonometric values that do not correspond to common angles on the unit circle, we will need to use a calculator to find approximate values for \theta.

statement.p: Find two angles in the interval [0,2\pi] such that \cos(\theta)=-0.4.

solution.p: Let's start by drawing a picture and labeling the known information and the angles we are trying to find.

Since we are given a cosine value, we know that we are looking for angles with an x coordinate of -0.4 on the unit circle. Below is a sketch showing two angles that correspond to \cos(\theta) = -0.4. Recall back to that these two angles lie in Quadrant II and Quadrant III since our cosine value is negative.

Since x=-0.4 does not correspond to a common angle on the unit circle, we need to use a calculator to solve for an approximate value of \theta. Applying the inverse cosine function we get that \theta = \cos^{-1}(-0.4) To evaluate this, we can use our calculator. Since the output of the inverse function is an angle, our calculator will give us an angle in degrees if it is in degree mode or an angle in radians if it is in radian mode.

image.description: unit circle with cos(theta)=-0.4 and only one angle shown

solution.p: We can now use symmetry to find a second angle in the interval [0,2\pi] such that \cos(\theta) = -0.4. From our work in , we know this angle should be located in Quadrant III. By symmetry, we also know that the two angles shown below are equal.

image.description: unit circle with cos(theta)=-0.4 and symmetry of two angles shown

solution.p: Therefore, to find the second angle, we can take the first angle we found and subtract it from 2\pi. This gives us an angle of \theta \approx 2\pi - 1.982 \approx 4.301 \text{ radians}
Thus, the two angles in the interval [0,2\pi] that satisfy \cos(\theta) = -0.4 are \theta \approx 1.982 \text{ radians} \hspace{.25in} \text{ and } \hspace{.25in} \theta \approx 4.301 \text{ radians}

image.description: unit circle with cos(theta)=-0.4 and two angles labeled

solution.p: An easy way to check our solutions is to evaluate \cos(1.982) and \cos(4.301) on our calculators. If our calculator returns values close to -0.4, then we know the angles we have found are correct. Using our calculator (in radian mode), we get \cos(1.982)=-0.3997 \hspace{.25in} \text{ and } \hspace{.25in} \cos(4.301)=-0.3999 Since both of these values are very close and round to -0.4, we can be confident that we have found the two angles in the interval [0,2\pi] that satisfy \cos(\theta)=-0.4.

statement.p: Find two angles in the interval [0,2\pi] such that \sin(\theta)=0.65.

solution.p: Let's start by drawing a picture and labeling the known information and the angles we are trying to find.

Since we are given a sine value, we know that we are looking for angles with an y coordinate of 0.65 on the unit circle. Below is a sketch showing two angles that correspond to \sin(\theta) = 0.65. Note that these two angles lie in Quadrant I and Quadrant II since our sine value is positive.

Since y=0.65 does not correspond to a common angle on the unit circle, we need to use a calculator to solve for an approximate value of \theta. Applying the inverse sine function we get that \theta = \sin^{-1}(0.65) Using our calculator in radian mode we get that \theta \approx 0.708 \text{ radians} We have now found one angle in the interval [0,2\pi] such that \sin(\theta) = 0.65. However, as shown above, \theta could lie in either Quadrant I or Quadrant II. Since 0.708 is bigger than 0 and smaller than \pi/2 \approx 1.571, we know that \theta=0.708 lies in Quadrant I. Therefore, we have found the angle shown below.

image.description: unit circle with sin(theta)=0.65 and only one angle shown

solution.p: We can now use symmetry to find a second angle in the interval [0,2\pi] such that \sin(\theta) = 0.65. From our work above, we know this angle should be located in Quadrant II. By symmetry, we also know that the two angles shown below are equal.

image.description: unit circle with sin(theta)=0.65 and symmetry of two angles shown

solution.p: Therefore, to find the second angle, we can take the first angle we found and subtract it from \pi. This gives us an angle of \theta \approx \pi - 0.708 \approx 2.434 \text{ radians}
Thus, the two angles in the interval [0,2\pi] that satisfy \sin(\theta) = 0.65 are \theta \approx 0.708 \text{ radians} \hspace{.25in} \text{ and } \hspace{.25in} \theta \approx 2.434 \text{ radians}

image.description: unit circle with sin(theta)=0.65 and two angles labeled

solution.p: Before we move on, let's check our solutions by evaluating \sin(0.708) and \sin(2.434) on our calculators. If our calculator returns values close to 0.65, then we know the angles we have found are correct. Using our calculator (in radian mode), we get \sin(0.708)=0.6503 \hspace{.25in} \text{ and } \hspace{.25in} \sin(2.434)=0.6500 Since both of these values are very close to 0.65, we can be confident that we have found the two angles in the interval [0,2\pi] that satisfy \sin(\theta)=0.65.

statement.p: Find all angles in the interval [0,2\pi] such that \tan(\theta)=7.

solution.p: Since we are given a tangent value, we know that we are looking for angles where y/x=7 on the unit circle. In addition, our tangent value is positive, so this means that \theta must lie in Quadrant I, where both x and y are positive, or in Quadrant III, where both x and y are negative.

Since \tan(\theta)=7 does not correspond to a common angle on the unit circle, we need to use a calculator to solve for an approximate value of \theta. Applying the inverse tangent function we get that \theta = \tan^{-1}(7) Using our calculator in radian mode we get that \theta \approx 1.429 \text{ radians} We have now found one angle in the interval [0,2\pi] such that \tan(\theta) = 7. However, from our work above, we know that \theta could lie in either Quadrant I or Quadrant III. Since 1.429 is bigger than 0 and smaller than \pi/2 \approx 1.571, we know that \theta=1.429 lies in Quadrant I. Therefore, we have found the angle shown below.

image.description: unit circle with tan(theta)=7 and only one angle shown

solution.p: We can now use our knowledge of the tangent function to find a second angle in the interval [0,2\pi] such that \tan(\theta) = 7. From our work above, we know this angle should be located in Quadrant III, and from , we know that the period of tangent is \pi. Therefore, the other angle where \tan(\theta)=7 should be located halfway around the unit circle from our first value.

image.description: unit circle with tan(theta)=7 and two angles shown

solution.p: To find this second angle, we can add \pi to the first angle we found, which gives us an angle of \theta \approx 1.429 + \pi \approx 4.570 \text{ radians}
Thus, the two angles in the interval [0,2\pi] that satisfy \tan(\theta) = 7 are \theta \approx 1.429 \text{ radians} \hspace{.25in} \text{ and } \hspace{.25in} \theta \approx 4.570 \text{ radians}

image.description: unit circle with tan(theta)=7 and two angles labeled

solution.p: Before we move on, let's check our solutions by evaluating \tan(1.429) and \tan(4.570) on our calculators. If our calculator returns values close to 7, then we know the angles we have found are correct. Using our calculator (in radian mode), we get \tan(1.429)=7.005 \hspace{.25in} \text{ and } \hspace{.25in} \tan(4.570)=6.975 Since both of these values are very close to 7, we can be confident that we have found the two angles in the interval [0,2\pi] that satisfy \tan(\theta)=7.

section.p: Using inverse trig functions, we can also solve for the angles of a right triangle given two of its sides.

statement.p: Solve the triangle for the angle \theta.

image.description: right triangle with hypotenuse and adjacent side labeled
right triangle with hypotenuse, adjacent side, and angle labeled
